head.supplied: Melbourne, 26th April 1893 ¶ Sir. ¶ ¶ In accordance with your instructions I have the honor to submit the estimates of the expenditure for the Gov. Botanist's ¶ ¶ Branch of the Public ¶ ¶ Service d...

div.p: V93/3407, unit 731,VPRS 3992/P inward registered correspondence, VA 475 Chief Secretary's Department, Public Record Office, Victoria.
MS written by Georg Luehmann and signed by M. Melbourne, 26th April 1893
In accordance with your instructions I have the honor to submit the estimates of the expenditure for the Gov. Botanist'sBranch of the PublicService during the financial year 1893/4.

As regards revenue I may remark that the sale of the publications emanating from my establishment at the Govt. Printing Office come to a considerable sum annually, though not as a direct revenue ofthe Branch under my control.
The file is marked 'Increase of £8' in an unknown hand and minuted 'noted' by Wilson on 5 May 1893.
I have the honor to be

p.seg: ESTIMATES of EXPENDITURE for the Year ending 30th June, 1894

note.p: This form is marked 'Office copy' in an unknown hand. M to T. Wilson, 25 March 1893 (in this edition as 93-03-25b) is an earlier version without percentage deductions.

Was this in Luehmann's hand, and if so not an annotation. Or added in CS Office?
Maximum £750

added

Or added in CS Office?

Was this in Luehmann's hand, and if so not an annotation. Or added in CS Office?
This looks like it might be by M who as far as I recall often spelled it like this

div.p:
Ferd. von Mueller,
On 31 May 1893 the Under Treasurer, H. Eaton, wrote to the Under Secretary, T. Wilson, regarding the salaries 'of £100 and under from which no percentage reductions are to be made. It is requested that the amended Estimates may be furnished as early as practicable and that an amended total of amount of percentage reductions in your Department may be given.' This presumably is the reason for the amendments noted in the Estimates above. Wilson forwarded the letter to M on 2 June.
M sent the 'Amended Percentage Reductions Total £131' the next day.
I don't understand this note
if I have understood the amendments notes correctly, because
the new total reduction is 133, which is higher than before, whereas the reduction of £2 made for 3 rd
Heb Ass should not be made thsu
reducing
the total???

26/4/93
On 29 September 1893, theLegislative Assemblydiscussed 'the vote to complete the vote of £1 ,607
for the Government Botanist. This has little resemblance to the figures in these estimates ,
V &P checked,
was 1607, but has an extra clerical post at £188. Need to chase when this was added.
[…] Vale began his criticisms of the amount involved by saying that 'this was another of the scientific branches of the public service, and there was no retrenchment whatever in the vote. The total expenditure for the Government Botanist last year was £1,479, and this year it was £1,607. He would like to know what return the colony was obtaining from this branch of the public service? It was simply created to provide an appointment for a man who was utterly impractical as the manager of the Botanical-gardens. For how many years was this to continue? He believed that the Government Botanist had passed the retiring age. He must enter his protest against this vote, and he begged to move that it be reduced by the sum of £1.'
L. L Smith came to M's defence. He believed Victoria ought to be proud to have the services of man 'of the high attainments of Baron von Mueller'.He realised that Vale did not refer to M 'individually' but 'to his official position', but pointed out that the 'expenditure in the Government Botanist's branch had been reduced to the lowest possible limit'.He pointed out that M received 'thousands of letters' every year from agriculturalists, that 'he had to paid for everything he required, including his stationery', that 'is office had been reduced to starvation point', that his assistants were to be transferred to other departments, that the officers in his department were grossly underpaid and that if the information in M's Select plants … was implemented it would add greatly to the exports, and thus the wealth, of the colony. […] Winter and the Premier, J. Patterson,endorsed Smith's speech, although Winter raised the vexed matter of the returnof G. Renner to M's department.
Vale stressed that he 'had carefully avoided saying any about' M; his point was 'whether, when retrenchment was being carried out, this vote was absolutely necessary. Men equally deserving had been sent out of the service, and it was a question whether, it was not better, from a national point of view, to discharge one man at £750 than to get rid of six men at £150.' He added that he had found 'scarcely a novel suggestion' in M's 'select plants for cultivation' that could not be found in agricultural reports in the press. He went on to criticise the economic worth of the 'millions of trees' planted under M's advice, and ended by questioning the value of retaining a man simply because he was a 'scientist' and asked if such experts were worth their high salaries. Vale's speech was interjected with comments favourable M by some of the members of parliament.
H. Wrixson spoke in support of M and cited the introduction of marram grass to halt erosion as one example of M's value to the colony. J. Harris defended M against claims that he had been responsible for the introduction of such trees as P inus insignis, and maintained that Select plants was one of the most valuable books printed at the Government Printing Office. He stressed M's international reputation and cited other important books he had written. [J.] Maloney endorsed the comments of Harris, adding that M's collection of plants was unique. […] McLellan, adding to the general praise of M, explained why he believed that 'no other public servant in Victoria who had rendered more service to the colonythan Baron von Mueller had done'.
The vote for the Government Botanist's Department was 'agreed to'.
